NATIONAL NEWS






Williams selling power-trading unit



May 22--Williams Cos. Inc. announced plans to exit the power business Monday through the sale of most of its energy-trading assets to Bear Stearns Co. for $512 million.  About 200 Tulsa employees could be affected, company officials said. Some jobs could move to Houston. The deal is expected to strengthen Williams' credit profile and allow the Tulsa-based company to focus growing its natural gas ...


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



DTE to sell non-utility business for $1.23 billion



May 21--DTE Energy said it has agreed to sell its Michigan Antrim Shale gas-exploration assets to Atlas Energy Resources LLC for $1.23 billion.  The deal is expected to close by June 30. In addition, DTE's board of directors authorized a stock-repurchase agreement program of up to $1.55 billion, up from the previous plan of $700 million. J.P. Morgan Securities Inc.


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Santee Cooper to buy from customers



May 22--MONCKS CORNER, S.C. -- State-owned utility Santee Cooper approved a plan Monday to buy excess power from customers who make their own electricity with solar panels and other generators.  "As a utility looking to the future and trying to be progressive, this is where we need to go," Santee Cooper Chief Executive Officer Lonnie Carter said. The utility said it will buy power from customers ...


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Energy co-op eyes Norwalk power plant



May 22--WALLINGFORD -- Officials with the Connecticut Municipal Electrical Energy Cooperative want the town to invest in restarting a Norwalk power plant, similar to the project nearing completion at Pierce Station on East Street. Officials from the Norwich public power cooperative were in Wallingford for meetings with members of the town Public Utilities Commission and Mayor William Dickinson ...


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Bills to cut energy costs failing to take charge



May 21--Senate Democrats in Hartford have sent constituents mail touting their work on bills to reduce energy costs.  But for the second year in a row, philosophical differences between Senate and House Democrats over deregulation could jeopardize efforts to pass any bills before the session ends June 6. "I think we're certainly at risk of nothing happening because of the gulf between the two ...


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Chevron is selling Dynegy stake



May 22--Chevron Corp. will sell its 11.5 percent stake in Houston power plant operator Dynegy, citing the changing relationship between the two companies and Chevron's need to focus on its main businesses.  Chevron said it will sell its 96.9 million shares of Dynegy on the open market through Goldman Sachs by week's end. Chevron first acquired a stake in Dynegy in 1996 when it transferred most of ...


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



BPA legal shift unfair to Oregon, critics say



May 22--Ratepayer advocates, industry regulators and electric utilities in Oregon rose in collective outrage Monday over a decision by the Bonneville Power Administration that would increase monthly bills for most residents by 13 percent beginning next month.  The increase applies only to investor-owned utilities such as Portland General Electric and PacifiCorp, which supply power to about 75 ...


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Solar energy helps pay bills at aviary



May 22--Tracy Aviary is harvesting rays to light up their Australian lorikeets, tropical flamingos and the stars of the bird show.  Photovoltaic solar collectors now grace the roof of the lorikeets' winter digs, a new building at the aviary that has the sanctuary's only south-facing rooftop with airspace unobstructed by trees. The collectors are creating enough electricity for the nearby flamingo ...


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Idaho Power customers to take hit this summer



May 22--TWIN FALLS -- Pull out the checkbook.  Idaho Power Co. customers will pay an average of $5.35 more on their power bills this summer after the Bonneville Power Administration announced Monday it will cut credits to utility companies. The cuts could increase energy bills across the Northwest and will block six regional power companies from combined credits worth about $28 million a month. ...

Gas plant opinions vary at sea, ashore



May 22--NEW HAVEN -- Broadwater Energy hired a marine service vessel to take media out to the middle of Long Island Sound Monday to show that the floating liquefied natural gas plant the company wants to build 10.5 miles off the Connecticut shoreline would be safe.  But when the boat returned to the dock across the Mill River from the former United Illuminating power plant, one thing hadn't ...

Selecting windows for your new home?  Troy Dally, vice president of merchandising for millwork at Lowe's, answers some questions about the choices you'll face. ___ What are the most common materials? _ WOOD: The entire window both the interior and exterior are made of wood. _ WOOD CLAD: These windows are made of wood but the exterior of the window is covered in cladding such as aluminum or vinyl. ...

Gorge locals blast plan for wind farm



May 22--A group of residents in The Dalles area has come out against a proposed wind farm along the nearby ridges of the Columbia River Gorge.  Wind farms are popping up throughout the Gorge, but this is the first time any notable opposition has arisen in Oregon. Members of the group, Families for Sevenmile Hill, say the wind turbines could cause health and noise problems and could be a danger to ...

Electricity bills from PSE could increase 13 percent



May 22--Puget Sound Energy ratepayers should expect a 13.2 percent increase in their monthly electricity bills triggered by a federal court ruling earlier this month.  That ruling by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals questioned the legality of Bonneville Power Administration payments to Puget Sound Energy (PSE) and other investor-owned Northwest utilities that collectively serve some 60 ...

Neighbors awake to explosion: 3 family members hospitalized with burns



May 22--It sounded like thunder.  Neighbors awoke from the noise around 3:40 a.m. Monday on Scott near Gratiot and Joy in Clinton Township. "I looked out my window and saw orange," said Samantha Schroeder, 20. What she and other residents of the street witnessed in disbelief was a white-and-brown home with a "for sale" sign exploding. A natural gas leak, according to investigators, reduced the ...


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Caught: Suspect in 17th Ave. fire: Speeding car hits homes, gas main



May 22--GULFPORT -- Police have taken into custody a man matching the description of a motorist whose vehicle struck a mobile home and a natural gas main, causing a fire that destroyed one residence and damaged three others. Police have not identified the suspect, but said he was arrested later Sunday night on a warrant for old fines. The crash and resulting fire occurred at a mobile home park ...


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Gas leak blamed in Clinton Twp. home explosion



May 21--The house explosion in Clinton Township early this morning was likely caused by a natural gas leak, fire officials said.  A mother and her two children are in Detroit Receiving Hospital, receiving treatment for burns. They are expected to survive, fire officials said. A firefighter was treated and released from Mt. Clemens Regional Center for minor burn injuries.


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



EDITORIAL: For thousands, a dark future



May 21--The lights and gas could be shut off in the homes of thousands of Massachusetts families who can't afford to pay their utility bills. Instead of leaving these families in the dark, state and federal officials should provide fast financial relief.  The problem started last year when Congress began handing out fuel assistance funds. Formally known as the Low Income Home Energy Assistance ...


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Daily News local briefs



May 21--Firefighters leave  before roof collapse FLOROSA -- Firefighters were ordered out of a house fire Sunday in Florosa five minutes before the roof collapsed. The fire started at about 1 p.m. at 216 Oakdale Ave., according to Florosa Fire Chief Mark Lee. Within minutes, the fire had consumed the roof. About eight firefighters were battling the blaze from inside the manufactured home when Lee ...


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



EDITORIAL: Building momentum: Bill Clinton highlights a ready way to fight climate change



May 21--How to slow climate change? The answers usually begin with coal-fired power plants and gas-guzzling cars and trucks. Rarely does the conversation turn to energy use in buildings, and yet this realm of consumption is the source of one-third of all greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide.  Climate scientists have argued that more efficient use of energy in buildings is a way to make early ...


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Public clear about cutting smog, but plan does minimum



May 22--After Texas officials rolled out their new smog plan for Dallas-Fort Worth late last year, members of the public had lots to say about it.  Some asked for a crackdown on new coal plants, cement kilns, cars and other polluters. Some asked the state to combat global warming. Most asked for an aggressive assault on air pollution in all its forms. None got their wish.


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Treasury seen opposing new tender for Ramat Hovav power plant: Finance Ministry D.G. Ariav: Barriers should be removed under the auspices of the existing regulatory framework.



May 21--The Ministry of Finance is apparently opposed to the Ministry of National Infrastructures' plan to publish a new tender for the building of a power plant at Ramat Hovav. Finance Ministry director general Yarom Ariav indicated the ministry's objections in a letter to Minister of National Infrastructures Benjamin Ben-Eliezer and director general Hezi Kugler.


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



City helps fund home repairs, keep work on track



May 21--Dave Harding is having a tough time getting a contractor to do all the work he promised on a home-remodeling job.  The bathroom in Harding's modest house in the Patty Jewett neighborhood is gutted. Lead paint chips are scattered in the dirt around his home, ruining his garden. A new paint job already is peeling. Harding, 53, would fix it himself if he wasn't disabled.


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Factory, neighbors reach possible compromise over pollutants



May 21--A Waco factory for bullet-resistant panels has reached a tentative compromise with neighbors who were protesting its plans to increase emissions of styrene fumes.  Waco Composites, 302 S. 27th St., now proposes to reduce its styrene emissions by 25 percent by altering its manufacturing process and possibly using exhaust vent filters, even as the company expands production.


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



What makes compact development work?



May 21--East Lampeter Township's supervisors in March increased the density of homes permitted in a Residential-2 zoning district.  That will allow a developer to build 400 or more houses on a 46-acre tract. Depending on your point of view, that was either a first-rate decision or a first-rate disaster. The Coalition for Smart Growth, which supports denser housing projects as a way to balance ...


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



City seeks the limelight



May 22--GRAND TERRACE -- Hollywood filmmakers have used the varied landscapes of San Bernardino County as a backdrop for dozens of movies.  But Grand Terrace has been mostly invisible on the industry's radar screen. City officials are hoping to change that by launching an effort to market the city as a desirable location for film shoots. "We're trying to put Grand Terrace on the map in a good ...


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Landslide threatens another home



May 22--STEVENSON -- Laura Foster never imagined owning river-view property when she and her late husband, Merton Foster, retired to the Columbia River Gorge four years ago.  Now that view comes at a steep cost. Foster's children and grandchildren, joined by community volunteers, hurriedly moved a lifetime's worth of belongings Monday as a fast-moving landslide migrated to within 20 yards of her ...


May 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Legislature takes aim at global warming



May 21--The Minnesota Legislature took steps early today to cut the state's contributions to global warming.  The Senate and House overwhelmingly approved legislation setting long-range targets for cutting greenhouse-gas emissions by 80 percent by 2050, with interim targets of 15 percent by 2015 and 30 percent by 2025. The compromise bill was approved 59-5 in the Senate and 125-9 in the House. ...


May 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Bethlehem developer to move to Allentown: Zawarski will switch cities to build new headquarters into old Schoen's building.



May 22--In the latest corporate relocation to downtown Allentown, developers Nic Zawarski and Sons plan to move from Bethlehem to a long-vacant building on Hamilton Street.  Under the proposal, the former Schoen's furniture store at 612 Hamilton St. would be renovated for the Zawarski headquarters, 18 loft apartments, and an upscale restaurant on the first floor.

Hemaraj to raise funds as interest rates drop



May 22--Hemaraj Land and Development Plc will float one to two billion baht worth of debentures in the second half of the year to take advantage of declining market interest rates.  Paopitaya Smtrakalin, director of Hemaraj's business planning department, said the industrial land developer was still studying the best type of structure and duration for the bond issue.

CITY'S GREEN ENVY



May 22--TAMPA -- Sarasota County is at the forefront of the green building movement. Hillsborough County is on board, and Pasco County is catching on.  And Tampa? Compared with other governments in the region, Tampa's is lagging behind a national and regional trend to offer incentives to developers who build environmentally sensitive buildings. Some council members wish Tampa were doing more. ...

Ohio OK's natural gas pipeline

California nut growers use sun for power, too



LOS ANGELES (Reuters) - The ample sunshine that has made California's San Joaquin Valley among the world's best places to grow everything from almonds to zucchini on Wednesday will also become a source of power at a huge nut farm there. TVA cranks up Browns Ferry Unit 1



NORTH MISSISSIPPI The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) has restarted Unit 1 at the Browns Ferry Nuclear Plant in North Alabama, completing one of the most extensive recovery efforts in the nuclear industry for an operating plant, according to TVA. TXU Energy Brings Storm Safety Awareness Campaign to Senior Citizens in Corpus Christi



In observance of National Hurricane Preparedness Week, TXU Energy, the City of Corpus Christi Parks & Recreation Department's Senior Community Services Division, the Office of Emergency Management and the National Weather Service have joined forces to raise community awareness about storm safety and preparedness, especially among senior citizens. May 22, 2007 PR Newswire



Algonquin Power Income Fund declares cash distribution for May 2007



OAKVILLE, ON, May 22 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ - Algonquin Power Income Fund (the 'Fund') (TSX:APF.UN) of Oakville, Ontario announced today that its Trustees have declared a cash distribution on its trust units. The distribution is $0.0766 per trust unit payable on July 16, 2007 to the unitholders of record on May 31, 2007 for the period from May 01, 2007 to May 31, 2007.

Williams to sell power assets to Bear Stearns for $512 mln

Commission to ensure balance in location of power plants



(NAN) The Nigeria Electricity Regulatory Commission (NERC) says it will ensure balance in the location power plants in the country. NERC Chairman Ramsome Owan gave the assurance today in Abuja in a chat with journalists on activities of the commission. The chairman was responding to a report released by the commission which showed that of the 16 licenses issued for power generation 99 per cent of ...

Tesla Energy Group, a New Division of Tesla Motors, Signs Development and Supply Agreement Worth $43 Million With Think of Norway



Tesla Energy Group, a newly formed division  Tesla Energy Group, a newly formed division of Tesla Motors, recently signed an agreement to supply Think Global with lithium-ion battery packs for their line of "TH!NK city" electric cars. The supply agreement covers the development and delivery of battery packs starting in December 2007 and continuing through 2008.

May 22, 2007 Business Wire



Eastern Germany's sunny future



(Fortune Magazine) -- The former East Germany, once one of the world's gloomiest places, has become home to one of the world's brightest industries: solar power. In late April ground was broken at a former Soviet air base near Leipzig for a $176 million, 40-megawatt photo-voltaic power plant, four times the size of the largest existing solar plant in the world.
